You really don't need more than this game to get full value for your Rift investment. If you're into the world of Harry Potter and love RPGs with magic - and if you ever dreamt about being a wizard - this game is a must have! Maybe it's just me having cleaned my glasses, but after the new patch (1.548 - a whopping 15GB!) it seems that many textures have been greatly improved in resolution and the performance too! I'm running the game on an overclocked GTX 1080 and i7 7700K (4.2-4.5 GHz) with 16GB PC3200 using highest settings and supersampling 2.0 - and I'm getting solid 90+ fps. It really feels like being there, the atmosphere, the humor and the ability to use magic are simply out-of-this-world. Remember that your Rift sensors each operate at 1000 Hz (I'm using 3 sensors for 360 degrees tracking - you really need it in this game), thus the faster you throw your fireball in the real world the faster it's thrown in VR - and there's just no way you can be faster than your sensors ;-) The full locomotion is brilliant (neither my son nor I ever felt motion sickness) and Touch controls let you throw, grip and manipulate objects - a true inspiration to how other VR games should implement Touch controls to make immersion perfect. BTW, try making a shield in each hand - now bring your hands/shields together and see how your 2 shields merge into one giant shield - simply awesome!
The game can be frightening for kids. My 10-year-old son more or less panicked when standing on a bridge and a 5 meters tall giant walked under the bridge :-)   
Although the action can be fast this is a thinking man's game (or challenge, there are quite a few puzzles in the dungeons - some optional). Consider your choice of spells wisely - and use them likewise! Don't judge the game before you've played at least one hour. 
Note that this game really isn't 5/5 - it's 6/5, and no I'm not trying to get the developers to like me, I'm simply stating the obvious. Wellcome to the dungeon!

review_feedback:
Hey there, thank you for the kind words and the constructive feedback. Really appreciated. Regarding your comment, what you experienced is “as designed”. As an early Oculus Rift+Touch title, our original design and initial release was for Snap/Step movement only. Due to fan request, we went back in to add Smooth/Free movement, but as you can imagine it wasn’t an easy process implementing such a mode designed for a specific system. There are certain moments in the game where you *have* to snap to location for key moments, so players always have the aimed teleport - which will always lock in - on their off-hand controller. Because of that, there are some points in the game that can be rougher with smooth movement, but if you utilize the aimed teleport in those moments, it addresses those issues. 

Anyways, we really appreciated the feedback and wanted to pull back the gamedev curtain a little to let you know why that was. Thanks again and thanks for supporting the game!

The controls are by far the best out of similar games, with the option to free move or skip move, free turn or not, teleport forward, etc.

review_feedback:
We are super happy you are enjoying it. (pardon the text formatting, it's being jammed together)

1. Try disabling antivirus for the install

2. Run the Oculus App as an Admin and attempt to update again. Right click the app and click “Run as Administrator”

3. Find the folder where Oculus is installed (normally “Program Files (x86)”) and make sure that the folder is NOT set to “Read Only” if it is, untick the box and click apply

4. Make sure that the location where the game is installed is not in the same location as where the Oculus Rift software is installed. If so specify a new spot that isn’t where the Oculus Rift software is installed and create a directory there to install any new games 


If none of the above solutions work, you can reinstall the entire App as an admin:


1) Interrupt the installation by logging out of Windows.

2) Uninstall the software: launch Oculus Home on your desktop, go to library, right 
click on the game, then select uninstall.
3) Exit out of Oculus Home.

4) Grant admin rights to your Windows account.  Go to Control Panel.  Under User Accounts, click on Change Account Type.  Select your account then change account type to Admin.

5) Reinstall the game.  Launch Oculus Home again, and reinstall the app.  It should be in the Library under Uninstalled.  Or you can search for it again on the Store.

-----
The step movement/smooth locomotion hybrid this game calls "free movement" is absolutely horrible. Lightly tilting the stick for a moment makes you take a slow, smooth step of a set distance. Tilting the stick all the way makes you first take this slow step, then lurch into motion. Trying to approach something you can't walk through doesn't move you up to the collision of the hitboxes, no, it estimates your movement based on some kind of tile system, and if you're about to move too close, it slides you away.

This game could be amazing if it just had proper movement. This botched insanity of a free locomotion implementation is just.. I *really* want to play this game, but I don't know if I can when just moving about is infuriating.

The menu system is really poor, too. It's just unnecessary friction. Friction upon friction ruining the joy of the rest of the game. Having "immersive" in-world elements is not worth it at the cost of ease of use. I don't want to be "immersed" in the game menu; I want to do what I went in to do & get *out* of the game menu ASAP.

I am sorry for the scalding review, devs, but my frustration with the locomotion is because it's a giant thorn in my side when playing a game that is otherwise delightful. Please just let free movement be free, no fiddling about with it. Movement speed directly proportional to stick tilt, with instant speed adjustment, and hard hitbox collisions. That would make *all* of this game delightful. And a simple clickable menu. That, too. Please, please, pretty please, and thank you. The rest of the game really is very nice.

Going to leave this game alone for a while and wish *really* hard that proper free locomotion gets implemented. If there's a possibility I could get to experience it with that, I'd much, much prefer doing so than suffering through with this movement system.

TL;DR: This is a great, polished dungeon crawler for VR. 

I am really enjoying this game.  It is delivering on the level of immersion I had hoped for from VR in the first place.  The locomotion system is adaptable to suit playstyles/comfort level, and the controls in general are solid.  Casting magic, in combat or to solve the numerous puzzles hidden throughout, feels solid and responsive.  The menus that involve drinking potions in order to make choices is clever.

In addition to being technically solid, the content of the game is fantastic.  The puzzles, combat, lore and aesthetics all mesh together to create a really fun and engaging experience.  Chucking fireballs with one hand while blocking arrows with a magic shield is exhilirating and satisfying.  The game is challenging enough to require adapting tactics to the situation, without being teeth-gnashingly frustrating.  The collectable items are a nice touch, and encourage the player to use the VR tools at his disposal; peek around corners, look in the nooks and crannys.  The customizable magic system is also a nice dynamic.

This is one of the very best games VR has to offer right now.  I really hope we see more and more like this as the platform matures.

review_title: A Sign Of Wonderful Things To Come
one_reviews_text:
I have been a true fan of Michael Crawford's 'Bards Tale' series of rpg's since the 80's and when I read that Bards Tale 4 was in the works I kickstarted that project so fast the cash fairly flew out of my wallet. Which brings us to The Mage's Tale, I was not an early adopter of TMT because at the time I was deeply involved in Fallout VR; however, once I booted it up I was SO pleased because TMT has amazing graphics, fantastic puzzles, true characterisation of the NPC's and most importantly, the sum total was far greater than it's constituent parts. To me, this meant that the same developers were definitely going to produce a high-quality AAA title in their new Bards Tale rpg. 
The only thing that holds back TMT from 5 stars in the emptiness, as in a bland 'sameness' inherent and duplicated in some of the areas. The voice-acting is of amazing quality and completely in keeping with the story and environments. The rich, in-depth magic system is a wonder to behold and use, that alone was worth every penny of the purchase price!

review_title: Good magical fun that could use polish
one_reviews_text:
Quite the atmospheric charm, a balance of the fantastic and the quirky that might remind one fondly of point-and-click adventure games.

A very arresting Gaelic song makes for a great introduction and recurring theme. Though maybe a little too recurring when you're hearing the same 4-8 words every time you hit a loading screen!

Spellcasting is intuitive, very comparable to other magely VR games. As long as you don't go in expecting to throw fireballs like baseballs, you should get the hang of it quickly.

The left stick's locomotion feels REALLY good. My favorite method in all of VR. I've been a big fan of this stepping approach ever since Technolust's option, and wish I saw it more often. Even better here because it's a smooth transition rather than instantaneous. 

Some little bits of feedback I would have for the developers in terms of "polish" would be:

#1: Audio sync with potion drinking. Taking a swig only to put it back down while the sound effect keeps chugging is surprisingly jarring!

#2: Haptics on touching interactable objects, not just selecting them. For instance, at the cauldron, touching that Lazy Susan of flasks to the right, to rotate it, has no haptic feedback on contact or rotation, while merely pointing at the color flasks does. That feels weirdly upside-down, doesn't it?

#3: Better syncing haptics with visuals in general. A prominent example would be the gem on the right glove that glows to offer a level up. The glow is constant and gentle, but the haptic feedback is a strong, intermittent, half-second or so pulse. Surely it would be better to either pulse the gem along with the haptics, or bring the haptics to a lower-powered constant drone. --- Whoa, we need line breaks in this review system.

review_title: No slideshow; A legit dungeon crawler!
one_reviews_text:
Hmm, far from an early impression and quite far in the game. Using the Oculus Touch controls and navigating, combat, the aim system all works flawlessly. If you played the old Eye of the Beholder games, the Wizardry series, Ultima Underworld, Arx Fatalis, Legend of Grimrock, or the countless JRPG dungeon crawlers you'll feel right at home. Once you master the movement controls you'll go from the traditional forward/back strafe movement in those games to combining it with the teleport to jump around and reposition yourself for defense or unleash a magical attack.

The crafting system and exploring your, sorry, your master's "former" lair is immersive and rewarding. [Explore! So much to touch and play with! Secrets to find!] Even early on without many ingredients I spent waaay too much time mixing, stirring and creating the same spells from the sheer joy of it - and the flexibility in the magic crafting system is impressive. 

Then of course, there is the rock solid classic inXile humor that harkens back to The Bard's Tale games. 

I will be playing the heck out of this game for some time to come. Along with Bridge Crew, one of the best executions of Touch and unlike most of the demo-ware, "stationary endless wave games" or brief 4 hour experiences... this is an actual legit game. 

My one wish would be to see a love child that keeps everything from this game and throws in some of the magical gesture gimmicks seen in Unspoken (along with co-op).

This is a no brainer must buy and anyone calling this a slide show must never have played a dungeon crawler. Your freedom of movement here and movement control surpasses L.o.Grimrock.

Not sure what others are running on, but load times are less than 15-30 secs* for me (installed on SSD) and frame rate hasn't dropped even later on during chaotic combat, particle effects, me ducking and hurling fireballs, etc (1080;4GHz Win 10 64Bit; 32GB RAM) so - yeah, this game runs flawlessly for me with no performance issues whatsoever.

This game was an incredible experience, especially toward the end.  The developers understood that we want to interact with the world in VR.  If you want to make a spell, you have to mix it in a cauldron.  If you want to exit the game, you must drink a potion.  Throwing spells means that you actually throw them at your opponents.  Because of this, the world feels alive and tangible.  You end up feeling like a wizard.  Furthermore, the graphics are beautiful and well realized, and the game has inventive puzzles that mess with scale and allow us to play with VR controls in creative ways.  On top of this, the fighting in the game is loads of fun.  This is the first VR game that I've played that has nailed every aspect of gaming that I enjoy.  There are some issues with the game's animation, especially the human characters, but overall this is the complete package.  It took me about 12 hours to complete, and I'll definitely go back to it again.

review_title: One of the better VR games out there.
one_reviews_text: For a VR game, and the first VR outing of the studio - it's a fairly solid product. It's a dungeon crawl, if you like dungeon crawls in general - you should give this one a go. You'll get ok-ish visuals, goofy story and dialogues which suits the setting and tone of the game, some puzzle solving, a free-ish range of movement. So far, for me at least, the weakest aspect of the game is combat, due to movement, reload times of the spells, and precision. I'd say the best implementation of combat where you move around is done in Robo Recall at this point. Here, devs tried to give you the option of teleportation and grid-based movement a-la dungeon crawl games, but it feels cluncky and I end up running circles around waiting for spells to reload and it's just not as fun as it could be. With that said, I got used to it and maybe it will get better down the line whether with additional spells or through the magic power of patching. With all that said - if your Oculus is dusting on the shelf and you hope to give it some use - give this game a go, it's one of the better and stronger titles out there, and I'm happy that Oculus had this gem on offer.

It's just the right amount that doesn't feel like hand holding but also isn't a head scratcher. The movement system may be a point of contention for some but it works perfectly fine for me. Mage's Tale may not turn out to be the best dungeon crawler by the time the first generation of headset are replaced but it has definitely set a high bar. If you're a fan of any of the vr dungeon crawlers that have been released so far then this is a must purchase.

But soon you will have to fight against tougher enemys, and the first problem occurs: The terrible movement system. The left analog stick lets you move in four directions in small jumps, the right stick lets you turn in small portions. So, while trying to avoid attacks or to move behind cover, the visuals alre divided into slices of a very fast stuttering slideshow - you will lose orientation and get headache.
In "exploration mode" I use teleportation with the right jumpstick, this feels much smoother but does not realy work while casting spells with your right hand.
The second BIG issue is the huge loding time of more than a minute. If you die in a fight or if you are in a try and error room with one shot traps and have to wait one minute after every fail, you wont love this game (and the song in the loading screen) as much as you did in the beginning.
